Award.AwardTitle: RCN: MSM: ETBC: Integrated Network for Terrestrial Ecosystem Research on Feedbacks to the Atmosphere and ClimatE: Linking experimentalists, ecosystem and Earth system modelers
Award.AbstractNarration:
As human actions increase the concentrations of heat-trapping gases in the atmosphere, climatic patterns are changing. Climate is projected to change dramatically over the course of this century, with average global temperature increases of 1.1-6.4 Â°C and widespread changes in precipitation patterns. These changes in climate will affect the functioning of human society, the functioning of ecosystems, and the status of biodiversity. The best available projections of future climate change come from complex computer programs that simulate interactions of energy and matter among the atmosphere, oceans, and land. Until very recently, the effects of the land surface on the atmosphere were only incorporated into these models in a limited way. However, recent research suggests that the way in which ecosystems on land respond to changes in atmosphere and climate will itself strongly affect the rate of climate change, and so the responses of these ecosystems must be considered. Historically, the community of scientists examining these issues has consisted of separate, traditionally non-interactive research groups. The INTERFACE network will facilitate interactions by bringing them together in a series of international meetings and workshops that are designed to make progress on a set of important, tractable challenges in Earth system modeling and experimentation.

INTERFACE will focus on training and forging collaborations among researchers at different early career stages, from senior undergraduates to post-docs. Students and post-docs will be recruited for active roles at all INTERFACE meetings, as authors of meeting reports and co-authors of resultant papers. INTERFACE will also broaden students' toolkits by sponsoring a series of workshops and lab exchanges that bring students together with the modeling and experimental communities. By providing cross-disciplinary training for the next generation of scientists at the beginning of their careers, INTERFACE can strongly influence the trajectory of future research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Human actions continue to increase heat-trapping gas concentrations in the atmosphere, further changing Earth’s climate. The resulting warming and widespread changes in precipitation patterns are affecting human society, natural processes, and biodiversity. Understanding the future consequences of today’s human actions is critical for informed decision-making.  The best tools for predicting how our actions will affect future climates are Earth system models (ESMs): complex computer programs that simulate interactions of energy and matter among the atmosphere, oceans, and land.  Until recently, the effects of the land surface on the atmosphere were only incorporated into these models in a limited way. However, the way in which ecosystems on land respond to changes in atmosphere and climate will itself strongly affect the rate of climate change, and so the responses of these ecosystems must be incorporated into ESMs.

 

Historically, the community of scientists examining how ecosystems respond to a changing environment had consisted of three separate research groups that only interacted in a limited way. INTERFACE brought these groups together to improve the design of field experiments, deepen understanding of ecosystem responses to changes in the atmosphere and climate, and heighten the realism of Earth system model projections.  A previous network had begun the process, bringing together researchers doing experiments in the field with researchers who use computers to simulate ecosystem responses to environmental change.  A third group, working on land-atmosphere interactions within ESMs, remained largely separate from these other two communities. INTERFACE meetings integrated all three groups, advancing global environmental change research by 1) facilitating the incorporation of realistic biological responses into ESMs, and 2) helping researchers design field experiments and computer simulations that could be used to improve the performance of ESMs.  INTERFACE held a series of international meetings and workshops that were designed to make progress on a set of important, tractable challenges in Earth system modeling and experimentation. These activities allowed cross-fertilization within, as well as across, these communities of researchers.  Discussions at the meetings led to publication of several high-impact publications, and more remained in development at the time the network’s funding ended.

Throughout its existence, INTERFACE focused on training early career researchers at different stages, from senior undergraduates to post-docs, and on encouraging collaboration among them. Graduate students and postdocs were recruited for active roles at all INTERFACE meetings, often as authors of meeting reports and co-authors of resultant papers.  Many of these students and postdocs are now in faculty positions at universities or in permanent positions at federal agencies or laboratories.  INTERFACE also broadened students’ toolkits by sponsoring lab exchanges that exposed students in experiment-focused labs to modeling, and vice versa.  By providing cross-disciplinary training for the next generation of scientists at the beginning of their careers, INTERFACE has influenced the trajectory of future research.
